titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
Morning visits, from Dr. Lewis Condict of New Jersey, and Colonel C. S. Todd, late Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary at the Court of the Emperor Nicholas of Russia. The Colonel was appointed by President Harrison, during his short career, of supreme command. He was recalled upon the accession of Mr. Polk, rather ungraciously, in his own estimation— He has acquired, during his residence abroad, something more, of the free and easy deportment of the military Character His notices, of the present condition of Society, at St. Petersburg denote the ordinary vicissitudes, of human life, at St Petersburg since the days of Alexander, and of his alliance with Napoleon, besides the transition to the subsequent war between them— I called this morning at the Navy Department and had a long conversation upon various topics, with the Secretary George Bancroft— I solicited again, some active employment, for Mr. Kavasales, a native of Smyrna, and Chaplain in the Navy of the United States— The Secretary stated his objections to his appointment at any of the stations desired by him— I mentioned the causes of which had occasioned the unfavorable reports, of certain Officers in the navy, concerning
Mr. Kavasales, and why they should not be recured, without much allowance, for unjust prejudices. I spoke also of the wish of Mr. Kavasales, that he would refer to Commodore Smith for a report, concerning his character, instead of taking that, of Captain Geisinger; which he promised to do— My further conversation with Mr. Bancroft, was respecting our present relations and differences, with Great Britain, and especially, of the contest, for the possession of Oregon. His remarks, convinced me, that what I have long suspected, that this controversy will be settled by humiliating, and pusilanimous concessions, to Great Britain, and sacrifices to the slave mongers, by the further plunder of Mexico— No evening visitors

Dr. Frye was here this morning, and excepting the time consumed, in a long morning and another afternoon walk for exercise, I was occupied a greater part of the day with my Granddaughter, in retrieving part of the arrears of this Journal— I fear a desperate task— I continued to write also for my reply, to Lord George Bentinck a task still more desperate, in as much as it has brought me, to the Bull of Pope Alexander the sixth granting the whole, of this Western Hemisphere to Ferdinand and Isabella called by him Elizabeth and their Heirs and successors, Kings of Castille and Leon— I find it in Latin in the first Volume of Hazards state Papers, and it puts me to a puzzle, for a translation of those passages in it which assign the motives for the grant; that is to say the promotion, of the Christian Religion and the conversion of the Savages, to the Catholic Faith— Alexander the sixth be it noted, was one of the most detested Tyrants that ever handled the Keys of Saint Peter, and wore the triple Crown— This is the justifiable foundation for all the European Settlements, colonial on the two Continents of America
We read this evening, the account of the Triumphal reception of Daniel Webster, at Boston, where he has gone upon a visit and the procession from the Railway Depot to the house of Mr. Paige, upon his arrival, while he is here, under the investigation of a Select Committee of five members of the House of Representatives with the professed view to his impeachment— And another Committee, is investigating the conduct of his accuser, Charles. J. Ingersoll with a view to his expulsion— No evening visitors—

There was no preaching at the Hall of the House of Representatives this morning, the process of preparing the Hall not being completed— I received two notices, one from Mr. Thompson and the other from Mr. M Pon that the Revd. Mr. Furness would preach this day morning and evening at the Unitarian Church. I attended accordingly and heard him preach from John. 9.35. part of the last clause of the verse. “Dost thou believe in the Son of God”— The Discourse without noticing the context, or the occasion upon which he spoke these words, to the man whose blindness he had cured by directing him, to wash, in the pool of Siloam and whom the Jews had cast out, for believing in Jesus— Mr. Furness commented upon the text as a general question, addressed, to his own Auditory observing there was even at this day very little, real, and practical faith, in true Christianity among its professors; that faith was like a Sabbath day garment, put on, and cast off one day in the week, and then he proceeded, to define, what he thought was true faith, which he considered, as a life, of obedience to the commands of Christ and not of any more speculative, metaphysical doctrines
or opinions— After dinner, at the Second Presbyterian Church, the Revd. Matthew Hale Smith, delivered his fourth and last Lecture of a series, and which was addressed, to Parents—his text was, from Proverbs, 29.15. the last part of the verse, “A child left to himself, bringeth his mother to shame”— Mr. Dietz a member of this Society had applied to me, with a request, that I would preside at a meeting of the Society, to be held immediately after the close, of this course of Lectures, with a view, to pass a resolution of thanks, to Mr. Smith and a request to him of a copy of them for publication— To this I had consented and had prepared a resolution to be offered at the Meeting— But before the beginning of the Service this afternoon, Mr. Dietz came to my Pew and told me, that it had been agreed not to hold the meeting this afternoon— The Discourse, like the rest, of the series, was plain, sensible, and edifying, without attempt at pathetic eloquence— It consisted, chiefly, of observations upon the duty of Parents, with regard to the education of their children, and in exhortation, to that rigorous system, of parental discipline, prescribed, by the Proverbs of Solomon— A system undoubtedly best suited, to the Age, and Nation, over which he, ruled, but perhaps, best succeeded by a milder, and more affectionate system—at the present day— In the evening, I attended again at the Unitarian Church, and heard Mr. Furness of Philadelphia, from Luke 10–27—“Thou shalt love the Lord thy God, with all thy heart, and with all thy Soul, and with all thy strength, and with all thy mind, and thy neighbour, as thyself”— The subject was treated, as usual, by considering this text, as embracing the whole duty of Man— It comprises the whole system, of Christianity, but I should be glad to hear, from a Man like Mr. Furness, his exposition, of what is meant by the love of God, so emphatically enjoined in this text, and so remarkably dis-
tinguished, from the love of the neighbour, with which it is connected— What is the love of God, and how is it possible, that a worm of the dust should entertain and cherish, and above all manifest, the passion of Love, for the Creator of the Universe. Reverence, adoration, fear, seem to be the emotions, natural, to the relations, between Man, and his Maker, and these are the sentiments, which I believe to be embraced, by the command of Jesus, in the text— The love of the neighbour, measured, by the intensity, of self love embed in the nature of Man, is a different sentiment though perhaps derived from the same source.— and perhaps still more imperative upon the practise of human life—

Mr. Kavasales was here this morning and I told him the result of my interview with the Secretary of the Navy, since he was last here and mentioned the promise of Mr. Bancroft with which it had been concluded, that he would see what he could do for Mr. Kavasales, and particularly that he would call upon Commodore Smith for a report of his opinion and estimate, of his services and conduct and character, in his station, of Chaplain— I felt it my duty to advise him not to place much reliance upon this promise— I continue to the extent of my decaying powers, to drudge, upon the preparation of an answer to Lord George Bentinck without noticing the torrents of obliquy from the British Periodical Press and particularly from Blackwoods Magazine, the echo? from the thunder, of the noble Lord in the House of Commons— At the House, a Select Committee of five was appointed upon the memorial relating to the blind, presented last Thursday, by Tibbatts— Reports were called from standing Committees, of which many
were presented and some debated, of little or no interest. I offered a resolution that the President of the United States, be requested to inform this House whether any Soldier or Soldiers, in the Army of the United States, have been shot for disertion, or in the act of diserting and if so, by whose order, and by what authority— The resolution was adopted without opposition— I offered it upon Newspaper reports, and Letters, from the Army of General Taylor, on the borders of the Rio Bravo, or del Norte, that he had shot, Deserters some accounts say three, others ten or twelve, in the act of crossing the river to Metamoros and these accounts are circulated in all the Newspapers, almost without remark of question or censure, as to the facts— The Chairman of the Military Committee manifested, some adat my resolution, but did not venture to oppose it— Committee of the whole House on the state of the Union, Preston King of New York in the Chair.— The bill for supplying the dificiencies of appropriation of the last year, returned from the Senate with amendments, was taken up, and debated, till after repeated failures of a quorum and a call of the House, to produce one, they were finally compelled to rise and report the fact to the House, and after a Call of the House, which produced a quorum, which again failed, an adjournment of the House, was finally carried without a quorum— About Sunset, I took a walk, making a large square, round Massachusetts Avenue—

This morning, Mr. Minot Terrill, with Mr. Abner P. Nash, both of Weymouth, called on me.— Mr. M. Terrill, had a Treasury note, for five hundred dollars, dated the sixth of March 1841. payment of which has been refused at the Treasury Department It is one of a parcel stolen from the Custom House at New Orleans, after it had been paid, and put again into circulation— It was received bone fide
at its par value by Mr. Terrill, and I called at the Treasury Department, to make inquiry at— The Secretary Robert Walker, was not there, but I saw, the Chief Clerk, McClintock Young, who said there was a Bill now before Congress to authorize the payment, of these notes, which could not be made without an appropriation— I received the same information in the course of the day in a Letter from the Secretary of the Treasury. Mr. Terrill and Mr. Nash, called again at four o clock in the afternoon, and left the City in the five o clock Cars for Baltimore— Mr. Terrill had not the Note with him but I told him, that if the Bill making appropriation for the payment should pass in Congress, I would give him notice of it; and he might then receive payment without difficulty— Mr. Asa Whitney was also here, and has a Memorial before Congress, for the construction of a Railway, to the Pacific Ocean— I promised him, that if his Memorial should come up for consideration, before the House, I would give him all the assistance in my power, for the accomplishment of his object On my way to the House, I stopped at the Office of the National Intelligencer, and had some conversation with Mr. Gales.— At the House, the call on the Committees for Reports was continued, after which the House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Preston King in the Chair on the Bill to supply the dificiency in the appropriation of last year. A tedious debate ensued, on sundry of the Senates Amendments, till the Bill was reported to the House which concurred with them all, and the Bill was returned to the Senate— A report from the Secretary of the Navy relating to the Marine Corps and proposing sundry alterations in its organization was laid before the House by the Speaker and after some debate, referred to a Select Committee— Committee of the whole on
the state of the Union Jacob Thompson of Mississippi in the Chair on the Post Office Appropriation Bill, with the project of a Line of Mail Steamers, to Europe upon which there was another long debate, and to which I paid as little attention— At the last Session of Congress, the rate of postage, was considerably reduced, and a compensation of the Postmasters, was also, thereby reduced, so that numerous resignations, for want of sufficient compensation, had followed. As a remedy for this evil a “proviso” was introduced into the present Bill, which Cobb of Georgia moved, to strike out— The Members of the Post Office Committee, and two disputations Members, from Indiana, Pettit and Henley, differed so widely in opinion, upon this “proviso” that they debated it until for very weariness the Committee rose and the House adjourned.— Mr. Charles. B. King, was here this evening— The Steamer Cambria, stranded about midnight last Saturday on the Beach ofoff Cape Cod— She left Liverpool on the 19th. of April, but brings no very important news—

I make but slow progress, in my draught of an answer, to Lord George Bentinck, by means of interruptions, from daily occurrences, operating upon the discharge of my public duties. Mr. McKay Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, offered in the House this morning, a resolution, that after this day, the House would daily take a recess from two to half past three o’clock P.M, and hold afternoon Sessions, objection was made, McKay moved to suspend the rules, which the House refused— Charles J. Ingersoll, called up a Bill reported from the Committee on Foreign Affairs, concerning the duties on Java Coffee, and tonnage duties on Spanish vessels— A debate ensued, in which Mr. Winthrop took a prominent part, until George S. Dromgoole moved the Committee to rise,
which they did, whereupon he offered a resolution that any Member of this House, who has been, or may be summoned, to attend as a witness before the Circuit Court of the United States, for the District of Columbia, now sitting in the City of Washington has the leave of this House, during the present Session, to attend as a witness, in said Court, if he shall think proper to do so. He stated, that he had received information from his Colleague Hopkins that he had been suppened, to attend as a witness in the Circuit Court, held in this City in a case now pending before that Court; that his Colleague had no personal objection to attending, but wished the House to decide whether he was at liberty to do so— A considerable debate followed, in which I took a part and had some sparring with Mr. Dromgoole, by objecting to the general terms of his resolution, and contending that if any Member of this House, wished for permission to attend as a witness he should in Court of Justice he should ask for it himself. finally Armistead Burt of South Carolina, offered an amendment, that this House having been informed, that Mr. Hopkins one of its Members has been served with the process of the Circuit Court of the United States, now sitting in this City to attend as a Witness in the criminal proceeding pending in that Court, resolved that Mr. Hopkins have the leave of this House, to attend the Court, in which I acquiesced, and it was finally adopted, by yeas and nays 76. to 44— The Bill for supplying dificiencies of Appropriation came again from the Senate with Amendments, to which the House disagreed, and sent it back— A message was received from the President in answer to the resolution calling for copies of the correspondence of George. W. Gordon, late Consul of the United States at Rio de Janeiro, relating to the
Slave trade in Vessels and by Citizens of the United States, between the Coast of Africa and Brazil. I moved the referrence of the Message and Documents to the Committee of Foreign Affairs, but a motion was made, and carried, that they be laid on the Table, and the motion to have them printed was refused— Another message was received from the President in answer to the resolution [“]whether any soldier or soldiers, of the Army of the U.S. had been shot for disertion or in the act of diserting and if so by whose order and under what authority”— Dromgoole moved that the Message and papers be laid on the Table.— I moved their referrence to a Select Committee— Haralson moved their referrence, to the Committee on Military Affairs— They were laid on the Table. A third message from the President was received, relating to Claims of Chickasaw Indians—which was also laid on the Table. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Lynn Boyd in the Chair, on the Jarva Coffee duty Bill, the debate upon which, was resumed—and after some altercation the Bill was passed and the House adjourned—

I prepared this morning three resolutions and immediately after the reading of the Journal asked leave of the House to present them— McKay, at the same time moved, to go into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, by suspension of the rules.— I asked him to wai his move to give me the opportunity to take the question on mine— He declined, but the House refused to sustain his motion. My resolutions were read, first “A call on the President for the names of every Soldier in the Army, shot, without trial since the commencement of the present Session of Congress, and the names of the shooters whether Officer or Soldier”— Second— “A request that the President would cause to be arrested and tried by Court Martial, for murder, every
Officer or Soldier by whom, or by whose order, any Soldier, of the Army, has been put to death, without a trial”—third “An instruction to the Committee on Military Affairs to inquire into the causes of the recent increase of disertions from the Army, and to report whether any further legislation by Congress, be necessary or expedient on that subject.” Immediately after the reading of the resolutions, Holmes of South Carolina said “I object I will vote for them when the War with Mexico is over”— I moved to suspend the rules, to enable me to introduce the resolutions, and called for the yeas and nays— A number barely sufficient for taking the yeas and nays, supported me, and the suspension of the rules was refused 45 to 90. Mr. Giddings of Ohio, moved to reconsider the vote taken yesterday—ordering the report of the Secretary of War, communicated with the Presidents Message, to be printed— It was merely a formality for bringing before the House, and the Country the real character of this transaction the shooting of deserters without a trial— He then stated the facts according to the report from the Secretary of War— At almost every sentence of his Speech he was interrupted by calls to order. but he did succeed in producing the Message from President Monroe of 8th. January 1820. in answer to a resolution from the House of the 14th. December 1819. concerning the shooting of a diserter by order of Col William King, and the proceedings upon the trial of Col King by Court Martial his conviction upon the charge, and the final Report of the Committee on Military Affairs of the House, requesting the President to strike Col King from the roll of the Army— But he could proceed no farther, the Speaker who upon the first calls to order had ventured, to sustain him, as in Order, finished by yielding to the calls of the slave mongers and declared him not in order—and he was silenced— This transaction, shows the present temper
of the House, with regard, to the dismemberment of Mexico, by the foul and detestable conquest of Texas— I bow in submission to the inscrutable decrees of Providence, but humbly ask, why sleeps the thunder in the skies? Stephen Adams of Mississippi asked leave to introduce a Joint Resolution for adjourning the Session on Monday the 13th. of July—objection was made— He moved to suspend the rules, which was lost by yeas and nays 101. to 62—a majority not quite of two thirds— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Jacob Thompson of Mississippi in the Chair. The Post Office Appropriation Bill, was taken up and debated at some length, but to which I paid not sufficient attention, to know what it was about, but the Bill was finally reported to the House, and passed—whereupon the House adjourned— The utter indifference and coolness not only, in the House of Representatives but of the whole people, to this shooting of diserters without trial, is a sign of the times, which affects me, with a profound melancholy at their degeneracy and corruption Never before has such a state of things existed in this Country and it betokens a depravity of Public Morals, which in my firm belief, cannot escape, the judgement of Heaven, upon the Nation— Evening visit from Mr. John Connell—

Daniel Willard, a descendant from the Willard family of Massachusetts and a travelling Bookseller was here this morning with a volume of Historical Collections of Virginia— A large Octavo volume, by Henry Howe, published a Charleston, South Carolina this present year, of which I took a copy for three and fifty cents. At the House Tibbatts of Kentucky of the Select Committee reported a Bill appropriating three Townships of Land to procure a Library of Books, for the benefit of the Blind.— It was referred to a Committee of the whole House, by yeas and nays, 103. to 54. After a struggle by Tibbatts, to pass it with
out commitment— He insisted that the appropriation being of Land and not of Money, the rule of the House that all proceedings touching Appropriations of Money, shall be first discussed, in a Committee of the whole House, did not apply— This day had been fixed, for the consideration of the Bill reported by the Committee on the District of Columbia to retrocede the County of Alexandria, to the State of Virginia— It was accordingly taken up, first in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Stephen. A. Douglass of Illinois in the Chair, and was warmly debated— The Chairman of the Committee, Robert M. T. Hunter, made a Speech, scarcely noting, the insurmountable objection against, the power of Congress, under the Constitution of the United States, to make this retrocession— Several petty Amendments were proposed and adopted or rejected, but the chief opposition to the Bill, was made by W. W. Payne of Alabama, between whom and Thomas. H. Bayly member from the Accomac District of Virginia—a violent altercation, with charges of impertinence, and defiance ensued. James McDowell, the new member from Western Virginia made an eloquent Speech, in favor of the retrocession— A controversy between Eastern and Western Virginia upon the basis of Slave or free representation, was involved in the discussion, but the Bill was carried triumphantly through the Committee; reported to the House, and passed under the Previous Question, by yeas and nays, 95. to 66. A formal Motion for reconsideration was rejected and the House adjourned—

I took a long walk last evening, around across the Tiber, and down to the Bridge over the Potomac, and after an almost sleepless night, find my reply to Lord George Bentinck languishing; so that I fear it will never be completed— I continued however to write, this morning, till the time for meeting
of the House.— On my way to it, I stopped at the Office of the Franklin Insurance Company, and received the half yearly Dividend by a Check on the Patriotic Bank, for Virginia Money— At the House, a motion was made to dispense with the reading of the Journal of yesterday, which was refused— Garrett Davis of Kentucky moved to suspend the rules, to enable him to present, three resolutions, of enquiry, of the President, for information, concerning hostilities between the American and Mexican Armies, on the Rio Grande, and whether any Naval Commander of the United States, has Blockaded the mouth of the Rio Grande or Metamoras— The motion to suspend the rules, was refused by yeas and nays—64 to 85. This is a sequel, to my resolutions, of last week, smothered in the same manner— Douglass of Illinois, asked leave to make a Report from the Committee on the Territories, but it was refused— John Pettit of Indiana, Chairman of the Select Committee, upon the impeachment of Daniel Webster, reported a Resolution, authorizing the Committee to sit during the Sessions of the House, and to employ a Clerk.— The request to sit during the Session of the House was granted, but that to employ a Clerk was rejected as was that of Robert C. Schenck, from the Committee of Investigation on Charles. J. Ingersoll, for the same permission— Pettit then asked, to be excused, from further service, on the Committee— Private Bills were again taken up, and a Bill for the allowance of the Bounty, on vessels engaged in the Cod Fishery to the Owner and Crew of the Schooner Success, wrecked without completing her voyage, was passed, by yeas and nays, 80. to 72, after a refusal to lay it on the Table 71. to 83. The Bill, for the payment, of a Revolutionary Loan Office Certificate to Nathaniel Bird was also passed after a sharp debate—76 to 66— I took part in favor of both these Bills— After some further unimportant debate, the
Speaker presented a Letter from David Wilmot, a Member of the Webster impeachment Committee asking to be excused from further service thereon being confined by illness.— He was accordingly excused, and Jacob Brinkerhoff of Ohio was appointed in his place— Committee of the whole House again, Caleb. B. Smith, of Indiana in the Chair, on Private Bills, one of which, was reported with recommendations that it do not pass, and another, in favor of a bfor the Fishing Schooner Tancred; and after much snarling reported to the House, which thereupon adjourned—

In the Hall of the House of Representatives this morning I heard the Revd. Dr. Welsh of Albany, preach, from 2. Kings 5.12. “Are not Abana and Pharpar, rivers of Damascus, better than all the waters of Israel? May I not wash in them and be clean. So he turned and went away in a rage” The Discourse was a curious exemplification, of the manner in which Democracy and demagoguism have crept into the Pulpit in this Country— The story of the cleansing of Naaman the Syrian is one of the most beautiful narratives of the Old Testament, but this preacher from Albany, turned it to political account. Its object in the Scripture is by a miraculous event, to display, the superiority of the religion of the Hebrews, over that of the Heathen Nations even of the conquerors of the Jews.— This is the perpetual object of all the Scriptures of the Old Testament— Naaman, Captain of the Host of the King of Syria, was a great man with his Master and honorable, because by him the Lord had given deliverance unto Syria, he was also a mighty man in valour but he was a leper—A maurauding party of his Army had invaded the Land of Israel and carried off
captive, a little maid, who waited on Naamans wife, and she said to her mistress would God, my Lord were with the Prophet, that is in Samaria, for he would recover him of his leprosy— So Naaman goes with a Letter from the King of Israel to the King of Syria with presents of immense value and the King thought, he sought to quarrel with him, but Elisha the prophet, went to the King of Israel, and requested he would refer Naaman to him. So Naaman came with his horses and Chariot and stood at the door of the House of Elisha, but did not condescend to see him, but sent a Messenger to him, directing him to go and wash in Jordan, and promising, that this would cleanse him from his leprosy— Thereupon Naaman flies into a passion and draws the comparison between the rivers of Damascus, and the waters of Israel.— selected by the Preacher for his text—and concludes by going away in a rage— Upon reflexion however by the advice of his Servants, he concludes to go and dip himself seven times in Jordan and is cleansed from his leprosy— He then returns to Elisha, the man of God, and acknowledges, that there is, no God, in all the Earth, but in Israel—and offers to Elisha magnificent presents; which he refuses. There is a sequel to the story, not less interesting than the tale itself, but of which Dr. Welsh took no notice, nor can I for want of time. But the Democracy of Dr. Welsh consisted in contrasting, the rank and pomp and grandeur of the Syrian Field Marshal, with the poverty and humility of the Hebrew Prophet— He commented much, upon the scorn, with which, the Grandee treated, the direction, of Elisha, and after many invidious contrasts, between the great and noble of the Earth, with the lowly condition of the Prophet, he finally concluded his Discourse by assuring his Auditory, that they might depend upon it, there was no aristocratic way to Heaven. After dinner I attended at the Second Presbyterian Church, where the Revd. Matthew Hale Smith, preached from Psalms 77–19—“Thy way
is in the Sea, and thy path, in the great waters[”]—a sermon, upon the condition of Sailors— Immediately after the close of the Service, a Meeting of the Members of the Society was held, of which I, was Chairman and presented a resolution of thanks, for his four Lectures addressed to young men, to young ladies, to married persons, and to parents—with a request, of a copy of them, for publication. The resolution was unanimously adopted, the ladies of the Society according to the practice of this church, voting as well as the men. The meeting, occupied not more than a quarter of an hour, and was then adjourned— At half past seven in the evening I attended at the Unitarian Church, where the Revd. Samuel. K. Lothrop, Minister of the Brattle Street Church in Boston, preached from Genesis 37. part of the 15 verse. “What seekest thou,” This is a question put by a certain man to Joseph, when he was wandering in the field sent by his Father Israel, in search of his brethren, who were feeding their fathers flock in Shehem but Mr. Lothrop dismissed all notice of this context, but taking the simple question “What seekest thou,” by itself and applying it, specially to his Auditory, said he would address each one of them, with that question, and inquire what they were seeking— He said it was probable, that the ready answer of every one would be, he was seeking for happiness—and then he proceeded to shew, that happiness, was not, in itself, the proper object of search for the Christian— That this proper object was, the development of his own character; the pursuits of life; of which happiness would be the ultimate result: the practise of the virtues, and the control of his own passions, which would lead to happiness, and which require An earnest examination and search, for practical application, to the duties of human life— On returning home I found Lieutenant Thom, of the Topographical Engineers here—on a visit to the ladies— Mrs. Smith left us yesterday to go to her sister Mrs. Frye’s
War with Mexico—

A message from the President of the United States, to both Houses of Congress, was received this morning, after the House had been one hour in Session— It occupied about half an hour, in the reading, recommending, not in direct terms, but by circumlocution a declaration of War against Mexico.— It begins with a referrence to the state of the relations, between the two Countries, presented in the Annual Message, at the commencement of the Session, and then relates, the series of events, diplomatic and military, which have since occured, and brought on a state of hostility now existing between them. A voluminous correspondence, accompanied the message, When it was received, the House was in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Samuel Gordon, of the tenth Congressional District of New York, in the Chair, upon the Military Academy Appropriation Bill—against which William Sawyer of the fifth Congressional District of Ohio, was playing off, his democratic Artillery. On the receipt of the message, the Committee immediately rose.— The Message, and part of the accompanying Documents were read, and after some altercation as to the mode of disposing of them, they were ordered to be printed and referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— The House went immediately into that Committee at the motion of Hugh. A. Haralson, of Georgia Chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs— George. W. Hopkins of Virginia, in the Chair— They immediately took up Bill No. 145, reported from the Committee authorizing the President to accept the service of volunteers, not exceeding fifty thousand men, with an Appropriation of ten millions of dollars.— A long debate ensued, numerous Amendments were proposed, a distinction between War and hostilities much discussed and numerous efforts made, to shape into a declaration of War, against Mexico, one of which finally succeeded— A motion was soon made, by Jacob
Brinkerhoff of Ohio that the Committee rise, for a resolution to close the debate in two hours, upon which resolution the yeas and nays were demanded and refused— At the end of the two hours, the Bill was reported to the House, with the Amendment declaring War by a lying preamble adopted at the motion of Lynn Boyd, and was passed by yeas and nays, 174. to 14. Amos Abbott, and Robert C. Winthrop of Massachusetts voting for this declaration of War. Of the 14, besides myself, Ashmun, Grinnell, Hudson, and Daniel P. King were five— Benjamin Thompson and Julius Rockwell, were absent. There is one vacancy in the delegation from Massachusetts. Thus only one half of the delegation from Mass voted for this most unrighteous War. Garrett Davis of Kentucky, asked, to be excused, from voting, for which he assigned reasons, perfectly conclusive, against the War, and finally withdrew his motion to be excused, and voted for the Bill— Thomas. H. Bayly of Virginia, did the same— Elias B. Holmes of New York—Albert Smith of the same State also voted for the Bill, protesting against the preamble, as base, fraudulent and false— Which preamble contained the declaration of War— And thus the Bill was passed, and the House adjourned—
Washington Tuesday 12th.— May 1846—

The proceedings of the House of Representatives, absorb all notice of any thing else occurring in the course of this day— After the reading of the Journal of this day—Robert C. Winthrop called for a correction of the Journal, in which his name had been entered, as against an Amendment proposed to the declaration of War, he having in fact voted in favor of it, which correction was made— Armistead Burt of South Carolina, said he was instructed by the Committee on Military Affairs to move for consideration of a Bill from the Senate, for the organization of a Company of Sappers, miners, and pontoniers Richard Brodhead of Pennsylvania, asked Burt to allow him first to move for an extra
number of Copies to be printed of the War Message of yesterday— Burt declined, and the House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union—upon the Bill, with an Appropriation of $25000. for the present year; Joshua. R. Giddings opposed the Bill, with an hour speech, interrupted by frequent calls, to order, after which a motion was made for the Committee to rise, The Committee rose, and the Chairman, Moses Norris, said the Committee had directed him to report the Bill— Which was not true— Burt who had moved for the Committee to rise, stated the fact, and said the reporter had erroneously made reported— Douglass of Illinois said “let it go as it is,” to this I objected— George. W. Hopkins, acting as Speaker, decided that the report was to be received as it had been made— Burt moved the Previous Question and the Bill was passed by yeas and nays, 153. to 9— A formal motion to reconsider, without yeas and nays called for by Rathbun but refused, and the House went again into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, Charles. S. Benton, of the 17th. Congressional District of New York, in the Chair, on the West Point Academy Appropriation Bill— Whereupon George Rathbun’s motion to abolish the Academy, as soon as the present Cadets shall have graduated, was debated and while William Sawyer of Ohio was speaking against the resolution, a message from the President was received, with a dispatch from General Taylor now commanding the Army, encamped on the Boarder of the Rio Del Norte— The Message was laid on the Table and ordered to be printed, and the House returned into Committee— After some further desultory debate the Committee rose, and McKay moved, to close debate in Committee in ten minutes, after the Bill should next be taken up in Committee which was carried by yeas and nays, 85. to 33. Allen G. Thurman moved to take a recess till 1/2 past 7. this eveg. Winthrop moved to amend it to take the recess till 10. o’clock this evening— After several unsuccessful motions to adjourn Thurman’s motion to take the recess was carried, 67. to 65— At the meeting after the recess, a
Letter was presented to the House, from John Pettit Chairman of the Select Committee of Investigation for the impeachment of Daniel Webster, stating that after having been refused the service of a Clerk for that Committee by the House he had concluded, to refuse to serve any longer on that Committee and therefore asked again to be excused, and that another person may be appointed in his place— He was accordingly excused and Seaborn Jones of Georgia was appointed in his place— Pettit was the mover for this Committee, with the avowed purpose of impeachment, of Mr. Webster— Having carried that motion, the real purpose of which was, to force the production of the secret papers, in the Department of State, he takes the first opportunity to get excused from serving on the Committee, well knowing that no impeachable matte, will be obtained by the investigation but trusting, that the publication of the secret papers, would operate injuriously upon the reputation of Webster in the Public mind— The whole of this transaction affords an exemplification, of the manner, in which the secrets of this Government, are divulged, by the operation of factious Parties and malicious personal enmities— Message was received from the Senate, returning the Bill declaring war against Mexico, passed by them with Amendments—which were concurred in, almost without opposition—. . . A final formal vote of reconsideration was made and rejected, and between eight and nine oclock the House adjourned and I came home with a heavy heart.

Morning employed, in writing, with a view to retrieve if possible the arrears of this Journal, which are growing like the leak in an unseaworthy Ship— At the House, Isaac. E. Holmes of South Carolina Chairman of the Committee of Naval Affairs presented a communication from the Secretary of the
Treasury in relation to the Engineers, for the Revenue Marine Service— Holmes moved to discharge the Committee of the whole House from the consideration of a Bill upon this subject, referred to them, and take it up and pass it, in the House—which was accordingly done, though in direct defiance, of a rule of the House, that all matters touching appropriations of money shall be first considered in Committee of the whole— This Committee of the whole, is in our theory of Legislation, the great security for the freedom of Speech, and of debate, upon all subjects before the House, but it is becoming little more than a dead Letter by this evasive practise, of referring subjects to the Committee, and then discharging the Committee from the consideration of them, without and consideration at all— This together with the other recent practise, of limiting the time, for debate in Committee of the whole, takes away, all the benefit of free debate intended, by that organization of the rules. The Committee was accordingly now discharged and the Bill was taken up in the House. It provides for the appointment of Officers in the Revenue Service, by the President by, and with the consent of the President.— Hitherto they have been appointed by the President alone— It establishes a new rank, of third Lieutenants, hitherto unknown in our Service, provides for additional Engineers, of Steamers, and increases the wages of boatswains gunners and carpenters—to thirty five dollars a month and one navy ration a day.— George Rathbun, moved to recommit the Bill, to the Navy Committee, with instructions to report a Bill to transfer the revenue Marine vessels to the Navy Department, which after desultory debate, was carried, 86 to 35— James. G. Hampton of New Jersey presented resolutions of the Legislature of that State, one of which was against any alteration of the Tariff— Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, Charles. S. Benton, of the 17th. Congressional District in the Chair, Military Academy Appropriation
Bill was taken up, ten minutes allowed for debate were consumed by Samuel Gordon. Rathbun’s proposal to abolish the Academy was rejected 50 to 94. and the Bill was passed. The Army Appropriation Bill followed, the chief debate upon which was a proposal, to raise the pay, of Private Soldiers from eight to ten dollars a month— About four o clock the Committee of the whole rose without taking the Question and the House adjourned— The Marine Band of Music played in the garden of the President’s House. I walked out and entered the Garden just as they were closing their performances with the air of Yankee Doodle. After returning home, Mr. Larned, together with Mr. Tracey from Boston paid us evening visits.

Mr. Kavasales was here this morning, and I had the unpleasant task to perform, of telling him, that the report of Commodore Smith, to whom at his request, the Secretary of the Navy Mr. Bancroft, had written for a report concerning Mr. Kavasales, was not so favorable as I had expected and hoped— That it contains no charge against him, of any specific misconduct, but merely an opinion of his incompetency, to exercise the functions of a Chaplain— I regretted this circumstance very much because it weakens the hope, of any kindness, on the part of the Secretary of the Navy. I believe him fully competent, to the duties of that Office, though perhaps well adapted, to exercise it on board of a Man of War at Sea— He wished me to intercede for an appointment at a Shore station which I promised him to do— I received a few days since a Letter from Dr. C. C. Cox of Easton, Maryland; inviting me to deliver
a Lecture, before the Ladies of that place, to contribute to the purchase of an Organ, for a magnificent Episcopal Church, recently constructed there— I answered his Letter this day, declining the invitation on account of my health, and a repugnance to be absent from my Public duties for a single day— At the House, Erastus. D. Culver, of the 14. Congressional District of New York, offered a resolution, to instruct the Committee on Elections to inquire into the propriety and justice, of allowing, John Talliaferro the pay of a member while engaged in contesting the Seat of John Hungerford in a former Congress, the Seat having been awarded to Mr. Taliaferro. But the resolution was not received, nor was that of Richard Brodhead 10th. Congressional District of Pennsylvania, for printing extra Copies of the President’s war Messages, against Mexico, received on Monday and Tuesday last— Brodhead moved a suspension of the rules, but it was refused. The Military Academy Appropriation Bill, was passed 90. to 41— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union on the Army Appropriation Bill— Howell Cobb of Georgia in the Chair, which George. W. Jones of Tennessee and William L. Yancey of Alabama declined. The Army Appropriation Bill, was taken up. James A. Black of South Carolina moved an additional section fixing the pay of the troops the same as that now allowed to the Dragoon Regiments— Tibbatts moved as an Amendment to raise the pay of private Soldiers, from eight to ten dollars a month— Upon this Allen. G. Thurman, the 8th. Congressional District of Ohio made a violent Speech, in reply to that of Mr. Giddings made on yesterday— Leonard H. Simms, of Missouri, followed in the same strain— Charles Hudson, made a spirited speech on the other side, after which the Bill was laid aside and the Fortification Bill was taken up with Amendments from the Senate, which were concurred in, on which the Committee rose, and after a referrence
of two other Bills to Committees, the House adjourned— I called this evening at the House of Mr. Bancroft, Secretary of the Navy— I found with him Mr. Walker Secretary of the Treasury— Mrs. Bancroft was riding out, and while I was there came in. Mr. Charles. J. Ingersoll came also, just as I was taking my leave and on returning home I found Mr. John Connell here

My call at Mr. Bancroft’s last evening, was occasioned, by a poor insane man named William Winthrop Allen, who had me called out from my seat in the House yesterday morning and inquired, if I had received two or three months since, a Letter from him, with a Memorial, claiming the sum of thirty thousand dollars, as due from the United States to him. I did not recollect having received such a Memorial but inquired upon what ground he made this claim— He then told me a wild incoherent story, of a conspiracy against his life carried on for a series of years, as indemnity for which, he had applied to the Legislature of Massachusetts, which had refused to do him justice, and thereby gave him this claim upon the United States, whose duty it was to indemnify him by compelling the Legislature of Massachusetts to do him justice. I enquired how he came here, and drew from him the acknowledgment, that he had been placed by his friends in the Alms House, of the Town of Medfield, though he was a preacher of the Gospel, and a Teacher of School— That from the keepers of the Alms House, he had obtained a permission to go to Boston, and had availed himself of that opportunity to come here to prosecute his claim— I assured him, that he could obtain nothing by a memorial to Congress, and advised him to return
immediately home— He thanked me for my advice and appeared well disposed to follow it—but he said he would call tomorrow, on Mr. Bancroft, who had been his Classmate, at Harvard University. Immediately after he left me at the House I spoke of him to Mr. Winthrop, and called at Mr. Bancrofts in the evening to notify him, of the visit he would receive from this poor man tomorrow. I proposed, that we should consult together upon the means, of prevailing upon him to return to Medfield— He is perfectly harmless, and eminently deserving of compassion— At the House, Columbus Delano asked leave to make a personal explanation, but objection was made and persisted in, till after moving a suspension of the rules, he withdrew his motion and gave it up. McKay moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union on the Army Appropriation Bill, John. R. Daniel of North Carolina moved to take up the Private Callender, which was carried— A Bill for the Heirs of Capt Larkin Smith, reported by the Committee of the whole for rejection, was rejected— Barkly Martin of Tennessee moved again the suspension of the rules to allow Mr. Delano to make his explanation which was carried— Delano complained, that his Colleague Thurman had misrepresented him, by charging him with having said, that the War with Mexico, was a “damnable War.” Thurman replied, and the debate fell into a mere question about the use of particular words, and ended in nothing. Then came up again, a Bill for the allowance, of the usual Bounty of the Fishing Schooner Tancred, lost at Sea, which was specially opposed by Daniel of North Carolina, and on the engrossment of which the vote was 82 to 80. Daniel then moved, a call of the House, which was refused and the Bill was passed 85 to 82, Committee of the whole on Private Bills again. Solomon Foot of Vermont in the Chair. Among the Bills taken up was one for the relief of Thomas Ap Catesby
Jones, for certain expenses, for services of a diplomatic character at the Sandwich and Otaheite Islands— Garrett Davis, from the Committee on Foreign Affairs, moved an Amendment, authorizing the Secretary of State under the direction of the President to settle and adjust the claims of Benjamin. E. Green for compensation as Chargé d’Affairs at Mexico, and William. M. Blackford for the same Office at Venezuela— Upon which a desultory debate followed, till about half past three the Committee rose for lack of a quorum and the House adjourned—

Morning visit from the Revd. Mr. Lothrop Minister of the Brattle Street Church Boston. He is to preach again in the Unitarian Church tomorrow and he proposes to leave this City on his return homeward next Wednesday— Mr. Lewis Johnson was also here, with a Letter from Mr. Joseph Otis New Orleans, relating to the final distribution of the proceeds, of the claim left by the late William Otis, not yet completed. I gave to Mr. Johnson a Letter for him which I had received last evening, from Mr. John Otis of West Barnstable relating to the same interest. Mr. Johnson informed me, that his connexion with Mr. Callen of a joint Agency Office, had been dissolved in the month of January of the last year.— Morning visits also from Mr. Charles Hudson, with a Mr. Snell from Boston, who claimed an acquaintance with me of many years standing but which had passed away from my memory. At the House Daniel of North Carolina offered a resolution, to establish a rule, for compelling the Members to vote in Committee of the whole House, so as to secure a quorum by directing the Clerk that whenever there shall be no quorum voting to call over the roll, and to deduct a day’s pay for every member who shall not answer at the call of his name
unless he shall make it appear to the satisfaction of the Speaker, that he was necessarily absent from the House— Objection was made. Daniel moved to suspend the rules, upon which the vote was 72. to 70— A majority but not two-thirds, whereupon Daniel declared his intention to persevere impressing this revolution, till he shall get a fair vote of the House upon it— The House had returned to the Senate, the Bill to raise a Regiment of Mounted Riflemen and for the construction of Military Posts on the route to Oregon, with an Amendment providing that all the Officers of the Regiment should be selected from the regular Line of the United States Army. To this Amendment the Senate disagreed, and the House now at the motion of Haralson, receded from it 96. to 69— I had not reached the House when the vote was taken— Thomas. B. King of Georgia, moved a call upon the Secretary of the Treasury, for a statement of the condition of the revenue Service—which was carried. An Order to print ten thousand copies extra, of the War Message against Mexico was adopted at the motion of Charles. J. Ingersoll— Brodhead offered a resolution calling on the Secretary of State, for the accounts of Benjamin F. Green and William. H. Blackford as Secretaries of Legation and Charges d’Affairs or Bearers of Dispatches which was adopted with an Amendment proposed by me to specify the items of account objected to by the Department— Committee of the whole on Private Bills. Solomon Foot of Vermont in the Chair. Sundry Private Bills were discussed and laid aside to be reported for adoption or rejection. After which the Committee rose, and the House adjourned. Evening visit from Lieut Thom— When I took my seat in the House this evening I found on my Table, a beautiful nosegay of fresh flowers, with a card bearing the name of Mrs. John Pettit of Indiana and the words “For Hon John Q. Adams”— Mrs. Pettit is the wife of a very eccentric Member of the House from the State of Indiana. With her I have no personal acquaintance and with him no
community of sentiment, or opinion— I think I never saw her, unless she may have been a visitor here on last New Years day— I hope it is no unworthy feeling, to be deeply affected, by testimonials, such as these— I therefore wrote immediately, to Mrs. Pettit, returning my thanks, with entire simplicity for her present—

Notice had been given in the National Intelligencer of yesterday, that the Revd. Mr. Tustin, the Chaplain to the Senate, would preach in the Hall of the House of Representatives this morning— I attended there as usual, but instead of Mr. Tustin a stranger whose name I did not here preached from Gallatians 6.5. [“]For every Man shall bear his own burden,”—a text, which suggested to me many reflections, I hope not altogether unprofitable but far from pleasing or satisfactory, but upon which, the exposition of the preacher made so little impression, upon my mind, that it has left scarcely a trace upon my memory— Whether this, is chargable, upon the Revd. Sermonizer, or upon myself, I am unwilling to pronounce, perhaps upon both. My state of mind being very ill suited to give the due attention to any thing, not peculiarly exciting, from the Pulpit— In the Afternoon at the 2d. Presbyterian Church, I heard the Revd. Matthew Hale Smith from 2. Timothy 4.7. the last clause of the verse—“I have kept the Faith.” Mr. Smith, related the melancholy circumstances, under which the great Apostle of the Gentiles wrote, this Epistle, to his friend and convert Timothy. The note at the end of this Epistle states, that it was to Timotheus ordained first Bishop, of the Church of the Ephesians, and was written from Rome, when Paul, was brought before Nero, the second time. Mr. Smith said that it was
written when he was under sentence of death. Upon what authority he said that, I know not, but there is internal evidence in the Epistle itself that it was written, before the sentence had been passed upon him— He complains, that upon his first Trial, he had been forsaken by all men,—but that he was delivered, out of the mouth of the Lion, and he expresses a confidence, that the Lord shall deliver him again and preserve him unto his Heavenly Kingdom— He urges Timothy to come shortly to him, and requests him to bring with him, his cloak, books, and parchments— Requests him especially to come before winter—and though he declares, he is ready to be offered, and the time of his departure, is at hand, there is nothing in the Letter, which intimates that the decision against him, had been pronounced. The principal argument of Mr. Smith was however upon the words of his text—“I have kept the Faith” and explaining by the context, the meaning of the words, he drew from them an exhortation to his Auditory, to follow the example of the Apostle, and keep the Faith, to the last moment of life, through every event that can befall the frailty of human nature— The Rev Mr. Lothrop of Boston preached at the Unitarian Church this morning and evening, but the weather was so uncomfortable, raining almost the whole day that I did not attend in the evening to hear him—

Mr. Kavasales was here this morning, he still entertains the hope, of receiving an assignment to a shore station at Norfolk, in Virginia, or at the Navy Yard, at this place—and I promised to solicit it for him, if I
should have an opportunity of seeing the Secretary of the Navy. Henry St John of the 6th. Congressional District of Ohio, at the House, by a suspension of the rules, offered a resolution which was adopted, calling on the Secretary of War, for a report at the earliest practicable period of the result of the examinations by the Officers of the Topographical Bureau, of the Harbour of Sandusky Bay, on Lake Erie, with a plan of the Chief of that Bureau, for the improvement of that Harbour. McKay, Chairman of the Committee of ways and means, moved a resolution for closing the debate, on the Army Appropriation Bill, at 2. o clock P.M. tomorrow— Which after abortive motions to lay it on the Table and to amend it, by substituting this day and next Thursday was adopted as proposed by McKay— David. S. Reid of the 3d. Congressional District of North Carolina moved to suspend the rules, for a motion to meet hereafter at 10. oclock A.M. The vote was 93. to 82. a majority but not two thirds to suspend the rules— The Bill to regulate trade and intercourse, with the Indian Tribes in Oregon had been fixed for consideration this day but was postponed, to the first Monday, in June, for the Senate to act in the meantime, on the Bill sent from this House, to protect the rights of American Citizens, in the Territory of the United States, west of the Rocky Mountains and for other purposes, commonly called the Jurisdiction Bill, which it is very doubtful whether the Senate will pass at all— Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, Howell Cobb of Georgia in the Chair, on the Army Appropriation Bill— Tibbatts’ motion, to increase the pay of private Soldiers, from eight to ten dollars a month, was further debated, but the discussion immediately slided into the justice and expediency of the War with
Mexico, upon which Henry Grider of the 3d. Congressional District of Kentucky made an hour speech, complaining of the manner in which both Houses of Congress, had been forced into the Declaration of War with Mexico, by blending it with measures, necessary to extricate the Army under General Taylor, from the desperate position, into which they had been drawn, by the order to march at once, to the mouth of the Rio del Norte— A resolution, for continuing, the temporary provision, for the Mail service in Texas, was received from the Senate and passed after discharging the Committee of the whole to which it had been referred— A motion to adjourn, was rejected, without a quorum McKay moved to take up the Amendments of the Senate, to the Indian Appropriation Bill. I objected to doing any business without a quorum, and moved a call of the House, which was refused, but they adjourned— There were this evening many shouts of victory and two or three half cannonades of triumph for reports, that General Taylor had defeated the Mexicans, at the mouth of the Rio del Norte and totally destroyed the town of Metamoras on the south side of the river with a population of about nine thousand inhabitants and so defenceless that its destruction is said to have been accomplished in the space of half an hour—

I have received a Letter from Charles Phillips dated on the 12th. inst. Secretary of the Historical Society of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill; enclosing two printed papers one the first report of that Society of which Mr. Phillips is the Secretary of the 4th June 1845, and the other a printed Circular Letter of the 5th. of September 1845, signed by David L. Swain, eight Members of the executive Committee, and the Secretary— Mr. Phillips Letter, referring to page 275; of the Appendix,
to the first volume of my Father’s Letters published by my Son.— The note B. thoughts on Government, states, that the manuscript of my Father, communicated in 1776. to the Legislature of North Carolina, has been recently presented to that Society by Miss Burke, a daughter of Mr. Burke who was in 1776. Chairman of the Committee appointed to project a Constitution, and afterwards Governor of the State— That he died in 1783, and that it is almost certain that from that year, up to 1845. the boxes which contained his papers remained unopened— They were then presented by Miss Burke to the Historical Society; and that among them was discovered one, endorsed in Governor Burkes hand-writing John Adams—Thoughts on Government— Mr. Phillips, on the part of the Historical Society tenders me a copy of this paper and remarking that the Society has been in existence only two years, in very obliging terms proposes to place my name on its records as its first honorary member— I am extremely gratified with the reappearance of these “Thoughts on Government.” though doubtless only a copy, of the Letter to George Wythe, published in my son’s collection, and many times before— At the House, we went immediately into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, and resumed the consideration of the Army Appropriation Bill, that is to say, of the War with Mexico, which was continued till 2 o clock P.M. when the debate closed, and the voting upon Amendments commenced. Tibbatts modified his proposed Amendment, concerning pay emoluments, and bounties of volunteers— McKay objected to the Amendment as not in order— The Speaker decided accordingly, Tibbatts appealed from the decision, which was sustained by the Committee 97. to 25— After the adoption and rejection of sundry
amendments, the Bill was reported to the House, and passed by 191. without one negative. The appropriation, is little short of seven millions. Sundry Bills relating to the disposal of the public Lands, were reported, and some other business of form transacted, when R. M. T. Hunter Chairman of the Committee of the District of Columbia, moved to fix Friday and Saturday of next week, for the business of the District, without deciding upon which, the House adjourned— The glorious news from the Army, received yesterday, was with some immaterial variations confirmed this evening— Of which we were informed this evening, by Lieutenant Thom—

I received this morning a check from the Speaker for three hundred dollars and Major C. J. Nourse, informed me, that he had ready for me, one Cincinnati Bond— I began writing an answer, to the Letter from Mr. Charles Phillips, Secretary, of the Historical Society of the University of North Carolina, but had not time to finish it— I have received also a Letter from W. D. Coolidge, Boston, inviting me to attend the annual Collation of the Unitarian Association, at that place— Which is to be, on Tuesday next— I deposited at the Bank of the Metropolis, a check yesterday received from the Speaker— At the House, the speaker decided, that a resolution proposed yesterday by Haralson Chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs for an Appropriation of money, to purchase a Book of tactic and the Articles of War, for the use of volunteers, was not in order, because every appropria-
tion from the Treasury, must by the Constitution be made by Law, that is by Bill and not by resolution— This decision was correct, but these appropriations by resolution are so frequently occurring that this principle of the Constitution will very soon, be broken down entirely— It has already in more than one instance, been violated and was especially so, in one case, in the 27th. Congress, against which I remonstrated, in vain— The business of the Territories had been fixed, as the special order, for this and the two succeeding days—but was postponed to the three first Legislative days of June— Andrew Stuart of Pennsylvania, moved to suspend the rules, to instruct the Committee on Military Affairs, to report a Bill increasing the pay of Volunteers from 7. to 10. dollars a month, and promising one hundred and sixty Acres of Land to every one who shall serve to the end of the War or die in the service. The vote for suspending the rules, was 70. to 75. Thomas Butler King, from the Committee on Naval Affairs, reported a Bill, for constructing twelve iron War Steamers of not less than twelve hundred, or more than sixteen hundred tons each,—of a speed not less than fifteen miles an hour and one iron Frigate to carry sixty heavy guns— With an appropriation of five millions of dollars— Referred to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union with the report and documents, to be printed— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, on the Civil and Diplomatic Appropriation Bill— James. B. Bowlin of Missouri in the Chair— Orvil Hungerford, of the 19th. Congressional District of New York, moved to strike out, an
appropriation of two thousand dollars for a meteorologist, that is to say, for Dr. James. P. Espy, who in that capacity, has been quartered in the War Department— Hungerford objected, that it was not in order, in the Bill, inasmuch, as there was no, Law, authorizing the employment of a meteorologist— For several past years, the Appropriation has been made, in the form of a contingency for continuing Meteorological observations, for various Army Stations— The Speaker said that it was not for him, but for the House to decide, if the appropriation was not in order— A long debate was started, on the motion to strike out the word Meteorologist, the vote upon which, by Tellers, was 46 to 53. no quorum— I called for another count but the Committee rose, and reported rose and repor no quorum. A motion to adjourn was made and upon the call for yeas and nays withdrawn— McKay moved a call of the House— Refused 53 to 85, a large quorum, and the House went again into Committee— Hungerford’s motion to strike out Meteorologist, was lost 61. to 65— After some further debate the Committee, rose, and George. S. Houston, of Alabama gave notice, of a Joint resolution, providing for, a one sided commission, of American citizens, to adjust, and determine, the amount of claims, of citizens of the United States, against the Government of Mexico— Sundry other reports were received and sundry resolutions of state Legislatures and Private Memorials, were presented, till soon after three o clock the House adjourned— Major Graham and Mr. Calvin Colton paid us evening visits— Mr. Coltons Life and Times of Henry Clay, has been published several months in two Octavo volumes, and the exposure of the real bargain, offer’d by General Jackson to Mr. Clay in February 1825.
remains without reply—

Mr. Kavasales was here this morning—but I had not seen the Secretary of the Navy, since he was here before and could give him no word of encouragement— The disposition of the Secretary, Mr. Bancroft, is in nowise congenial with his former profession, as a Minister of the Gospel— He in nowise favors the establishment of Chaplains in the Naval Service, and seems to think, that Seamen have nothing to do with religion, and that the abolition of all religious services, from the Navy of the United States, whether in the Land or on the Sea, might be the most expedient policy— At the House, a Bill was introduced by George Rathbun for making copies of papers, certified by the Secretary of the Senate, or the Clerk of the House of Representatives, lawful evidence in the Courts of Justice in the States, which Bill was passed and sent to the Senate— W. W. Payne of Alabama, moved to discharge the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, from the consideration of a Bill to amend and continue in enforce the Act to incorporate the inhabitants of the City of Washington which was done and the Bill was taken up in the House— The previous Question upon its engrossment, was rejected— R. M. T. Hunter moved an Amendment substituting another Bill, recommended by a convention of delegates of the people of Washington— Motions were made to lay the Bill on the Table, which were rejected The substitute moved by Hunter, was rejected by yeas and nays 60. to 99. Paynes Bill was passed and sent
to the senate without filling the blank in it. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union George. W. Hopkins in the Chair, and the Civil and Diplomatic appropriation Bill was taken up upon the first Question, of a proposed amendment, there was no quorum voting— The Committee rose, and reported the fact, a call of the House was moved and rejected 84. to 47. Showing 131. members present—112. making a quorum. The House thereupon went again into Committee and resumed the debate— Grover of New York spoke three or four times, whereupon Dromgoole appealed to the rule that no member should speak more than twice to the same question without leave of the House, nor more than once, until every other member choosing to speak, shall have spoken. Motion was made that Grover should have leave to speak again. Vote 45. to 21. no quorum—whereupon the House adjourned—

Morning visit from Dr W. B. Webster of Kentville Nova Scotia. When I was there in September 1840. we passed a Sunday at that place—and in the afternoon of that day, I took a ride with this gentleman, and his brother, of four or five miles, to see a tract of Country, reclaimed, from the Sea, in the Town of Cornwallis— This is the second person, of those whom we met on that day, who has strolled thus far, on a visit to the States; without any other apparent motive, than curiosity— At the House, Isaac. E. Holmes of South Carolina Chairman of the Committee on Naval Affairs, reported back a Bill from the Senate, referred to that Committee, repealing the proviso in the Navy Appropriation Act limiting the number of petty Officers, Seamen, Landsmen, and boys, to 7500. with an Amendment,—
which was passed, and the Bill returned, to the Senate— Robert McClelland of Michigan Chairman of the Committee on Commerce, reported a Bill for allowance of drawback, on articles imported from the British North American Colonies and exported to Foreign Countries which after some feeble obstruction was passed and sent to the Senate— The House was thin, and a quorum failing Meredith. P. Gentry of Tennessee, moved to adjourn over to Monday, to give the members of the House the opportunity to visit the great National Fair of American Manufactures, which commenced yesterday, but his proposition was rejected 65 to 93— Committee of the whole on Private Bills, Charles Hudson, in the Chair— The first and fourth Friday in each month, are assigned for the consideration of Bills, to which no objection is made, and if as they are called over any one member objects and persists in the objection to any Bill it must be passed by— Eight Bills were thus called, without objection. At last a Bill for the relief of Ann and L. Dana and Co. was called, and objected to by Wm. Sawyer of Ohio— It was passed over, and another Bill, taken up without objection after which Sawyer withdrew his objection, which George S. Houston of Alabama insisted he could not do, the Committee having no power to step backward. The Chairman decided that the Bill should be reported to the House, from which George. W. Jones of Tennessee appealed, and after three votes without a quorum the decision of the Chairman was sustained— Jones thereupon objected to all the Bills which had been laid aside to be reported, which the Chair
man decided was not in order— Eighteen Bills were called up, and objected to. James A. Black of South Carolina moved the Committee to rise and report the Bill as passed upon—no quorum voting— The Committee rose and reported the fact John R. J. Daniel of North Carolina moved a call of the House Vinton of Ohio moved to adjourn— Refused 30. to 74— No quorum— Daniel’s motion for a Call was then rejected, and the House adjourned— Evening Party at Mr. Grinnells and Mr. Winthrop’s—to which I went alone the Ladies all sending excuses— I met there many strangers visiting the City to see the Fair, and otherwise— Among the rest Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Appleton, and others from Boston— I remained but a short time, being myself quite unwell—

I answered the Letter of Charles Phillips Secretary of the Historical Society of the University of North Carolina, at Chapel Hill, and accepted the offer, of a copy of my Father’s “Thoughts on Government”—and also that of being an honorary member of the Society. I answered also, W. D. Coolidge’s Letter Boston—inviting me to attend at the annual Collation, of the Unitarian Association, Boston next Tuesday—which I am of course obliged to decline— At the House, David. S. Reid of North Carolina moved to reconsider the vote, taken yesterday, to repeal the limitation, of last year’s navy appropriation Bill of Seamen to 7500. But the consideration of the motion was postponed. Haralson Chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs, reported back a Bill from the Senate increasing the number of Paymasters in the Army—which was referred
to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union— F. P. Stanton of Tennessee by direction of naval Committee asked leave to submit a motion to print five thousand copies extra of Thomas. B. Kings report on the increase of the navy and the building of twelve Iron War Steamers and an iron Frigate of sixty guns— John R. J Daniel objected Cornelius Darragh moved to suspend the rules to receive the motion, which was refused— The Private Callender was taken up at the motion of Daniel Chairman of the committee on Claims— The Bill for the allowance of Bounty for the Fishing Schooner Florilla, lost at Sea was read the third time, and on taking the Question by yeas and nays, the Speaker announced the vote 77. to 76 and declared the Bill to be passed— Daniel asked if the Speaker had voted and he answered no— Daniel enquired if he had voted whether it would have changed the result? he answered no— Now if he had voted against the Bill it would have made a tie and the Bill would have been lost— Sometime afterwards the Speaker said, that upon reexamining the vote, the Clerk had discovered that it had been a tie 77 to 77. and that he voted himself, making the vote 77. to 78. and rejecting the Bill— This is a perfect exemplification of the characteristic discriminations of John W. Davis, the present Speaker of the House of Representatives— If his vote would have rejected the Bill by making a tie, he would not have given it, but when the Bill was rejected, by a tie, he would have added his own vote, to make the assurance of rejection, doubly sure— Some question was made whether after the announcement, that the Bill was
passed, it was not too late, especially by such a questionable procedure, to reverse the decision— Other objections were made, to the voting of the Speaker, but without any result, except to show his passion for the strongest side— The House adjourned between two and three o clock, and I walked round and visited the Fair— After dinner I walked again to the Capitol, where the Musicians of the Marine Band, were performing— I expected to find the ladies with the Carriage there but was disappointed, and had to walk home— Mr. Hague the astrologer was here in the evening with many mysterious prophetic givings out, which he promised, to explain to me, some day next week, but which as usual amount to nothing— An Indian of the Stockbridge Tribe, by the name of John Quinney was also here—

My strength was over strained yesterday, by the exercise of walking beyond my present powers, and the Summer heat has come on, rather prematurely— I never the less attended, this morning Public Worship at the Hall of the House of Representatives— The Preacher was a stranger but whether from being much indisposed, and suffering from the heat of the weather, I could pay so little attention to his discourse that I have no recollection, either of his text or of his commentary— I must say the same, of the afternoon sermon, which I heard at the Second Presbyterian Church, also from a stranger who supplied the place of Mr. Matthew Hale Smith— In the evening we had as visitors, Mr. Arch
ibald Campbell, now Chief Clerk in the Department of War, Isaac Hull Adams, and Mr. Healey the Painter—who took leave of us— He intends to leave the City next Wednesday, goes first to New York, then to Boston, and embarks for France next August— He came to this Country last May was a twelve month commissioned by Louis Phillipe the present King of France, to paint for him three portraits, of the late President Andrew Jackson, of Mr. Henry Clay of Kentucky and of me— He arrived barely in time, to take the portrait of General Jackson, which he finished only four days before his death— He then went to Ashland, where he took the portrait of Mr. Clay, and then came to Boston and painted mine, in September last— They have all been exhibited, in the rotundo of the Capitol, with many others which he has painted during his Winter residence here— All remarkable pictures, and admirable likenesses— About two or three months since, he sent mine to Boston, to be engraved. Almost all the others are still in the rotundo Besides these, he has made also for the King of France copies of several other portraits of persons, distinguished in our Revolutionary History and among them of Gilbert Stuarts portrait of my Father, painted while he was President of the United States, which is at Quincy with the portrait of my mother by the same Artist— That of my Father, was borrowed of me by Mr. Healey and kept by him several weeks— Mr. Healeys companion Dubourjal has already left this place

I have received a Letter, from P. W. Chandler Treasurer of the Massachusetts Historical Society, informing me that two subscriptions have been opened for that Society one for the payment of a debt contracted, by the publication of the last volume of their collection and the other for the re-publication of some of the preceding volumes. Of this last he says the subscription already made is sufficient, but for the other, he solicits a contribution from me— I answered his Letter this day, requesting him to subscribe 50. dolls for me, and referred him to my Son for the payment— At the House this morng. Jacob Brinkerhoff of Ohio moved a suspension of the rules, to offer a joint resolution of thanks to Brevet Brigadier General Zachary Taylor commanding the Army of occupation, his Officers and men, for the fortitude, skill, enterprise, and courage, which have distinguished the recent, brilliant operations on the Rio Grande and a second resolution, authorizing and directing the President to cause to be paid to each non-commissioned Officer, musician and Private belonging to said army, on the 9th. instt. one month’s additional pay. to be paid out of any money in the Treasury, not otherwise appropriated— Robert. C. Winthrop declaring his cordial approbation of the resolutions enquired if any official despatches, relating to these victories, had been received and communicated to Congress— Brinkerhoff said there had not— He only wished to get the resolutions before the House until the dispatches should be received They were received twice read and referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union I had not reached my seat in the House Committee of the whole on the state of the Union George. W. Hopkins in the Chair, on the Civil and
diplomatic Appropriation Bill Daniel. P. King moved to insert an item to supply the difficiency in the fund, for the relief of sick and disabled seamen, 25000. dollars—which after a long debate, was agreed to, 79. to 45 Then came an item for the erection and completion of the Marine Hospitals at Pittsburg, Louisville, and Cleavland. 50.000 dollars— Boyd of Kentucky moved to insert Paducah, after Louisville, without increasing the appropriation— This started a long debate, Jefferson Davis of Mississippi moved to add Natchez, with a long speech— Joseph. J McDowell named Cincinnati.— Other places on the western rivers were also suggested and debated, till, when they came to vote, there was no quorum— The Committee rose, on a motion for adjournment— 141. members voted. They went into Committee again— W. W. Woodworth of the eighth Congressional District of New York moved, to reconsider the vote, of last Saturday, rejecting the Bill for the relief of the owners of the Fishing Schooner Florilla, which motion was entered, and postponed— Daniel, of North Carolina, moved also to reconsider the vote of the same day, rejecting the Bill, for the relief of Alborn Allen. Also postponed. The Post Office Bill, from the Senate, was referred to the Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads, several Executive communications were laid by the Speaker before the House and they adjourned about three o’clock.

Mr. Frye was here this morning and brought two Letters from Captain Robert C. Buchanan to his mother, from the Field of Battle, in the Rio Grande— The second
