of them being written on a sheet of paper taken with the Camp equipage of the Mexican General Arista— The route of the Mexican Army was complete, and they retreated beyond the river— At the House, Jacob Brinkerhoff of Ohio, was very impatient, to take up his resolution of thanks to General Taylor and his Army, which he had offered yesterday, but consented to wait for the Message from the President, with the Official despatches— The Civil and Diplomatic appropriation Bill was taken up and Lynn Boyd’s motion, to introduce an additional Marine Hospital at Paducah, came up again, and produced another stubborn debate. Crozier of Tennessee, Houston of Alabama, Stanton of Tennessee, Jefferson Davis of Mississippi, who renewed his motion to insert Natchez, Wentworth of Illinois, Darragh of Pennsylvania, James. F. Faran of Ohio, and James. B. Bowlin of Missouri, discussed, the insertion of various places, till Martin Grover, of New York, moved, to strike out the whole Section— He and Payne of Alabama, made speeches, against the whole system of Marine Hospitals as appendages to that of internal improvement. Howell Cobb of Georgia, carried a motion for the Committee to rise, and then the resolution to close the debate in Committee of the whole, at one o clock, P.M. tomorrow— After which and some struggling the House adjourned—

Mr. Bird Chamberlain was here this morning with a new English translation of Homer’s Illiad in blank verse, by Wm. Mumford—a native of Mecklinburg County, Virginia born on the 15th. August 1775. and deceased at Richmond 21st. June 1825. How a man could have the courage, to
write a translation in English blank verse after the rhymes of Pope, and the two translations of Cowper, I find it difficult to imagine; but I agreed to take a copy of the work, for the curiosity of the case, and for the benefit of Mr. Mumfords widow, by whom it is published twenty years after his death— Mr Schenck Chairman of the Committee of Investigation in the case of Charles. J. Ingersoll, but into my hands four interrogatories, in writing, on the part of that Committee requesting me to answer them, at my convenience— At the House Haralson Chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs moved a call upon the President for all the Official Despatches from General Taylor, relating to the Battles of the 8th. and 9th. instt., which was adopted— Committee of the whole on the State of the Union George W. Hopkins in the Chair, on the Civil and Diplomatic Appropriation Bill— A debate followed and Jacob Collamer of Vermont in a calm, argumentative and efficient speech, replied to the Anti-Tariff invective, yesterday pronounced, by W. W. Payne, of Alabama— He was followed by Andrew Stuart of Pennsylvania, who spoke till the time came for closing the debate— His Speech was as usual, highly animated and forcebal? in favor of Protective Policy Payne, by a low cunning common to all the Southern Anti-Tariffites affects to charge the Tariff as exclusively favorable to the interest of New England—but Stuart is a Pennsylvanian and Pensylvania has a far deeper interest in the Tariff Policy than New England— The debate being arrested, the voting commenced and sundry amendments were adopted— The item for the Marine Hospitals was struck out and two attempts, partially to re-insert it, were
rejected— An appropriation for the sixth volume, of the fourth series, of the documentary History of the United States of 25.449. dollars, offered by R. C. Winthrop by direction of the Committee of Ways and Means, was carried, by being made payable, to Blair and Rives— Winthrop moved an item of $18000. for a Commissioner to Mexico whenever the President shall ascertain that he will be received— Rejected 50. to 81. There was an item of $5000. for the Salary of a Commissioner to reside in China, to which Jacob Thompson moved a proviso, that no part of this Sum shall be paid, without a Certificate on honor from the said Commissioner that he does reside in China; which after being amended at the motion of George Rathbun to read “That the salary shall not be paid unless the Commissioner shall actually reside in China” was adopted 74 to 40. This was a kick at Alexander. H. Everett, who fourteen months ago, embarked for China, went as far as Rio de Janeiro, and returned, from thence, on account of ill-health. He has ever since been living here receiving the salary, and promising to re-embark when his health should be sufficiently restored— John. P. Martin of Kentucky and Joseph. J. McDowell of Ohio, made clap trap motions, for reducing pay and travel of Members of Congress in the midst of which small work, the message with General Taylor’s Despatches, was received from the President, referred to the Military Committee, and ordered to be printed Haralson, reported a Bill to provide certain military tactics for the use of volunteers twice read and Committed— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, again on the Civil and Diplomatic Appropriation Bill— More motions for bunkum, to reduce the pay and the mileage and to forfeit pay, for
non-attendance—the most senseless of which were carried— Yell of Arkansas moved an additional section to the Bill to remove the seat of Government in 1850, to St Louis Missouri which the Chairman ruled, not to be in order— Bell of Kentucky, Stephen Adams of Mississippi and Bowlin of Missouri, moved sundry other retrenchment nonsense, till the quorum entirely failed, the Committee rose and the House adjourned— In the evening I attended at a large Party, given by Mr. Joseph. R. Ingersoll, at the House of Mr. Markoe given to Mr. Christopher Hughes, and his daughter, and a company of friends from Baltimore— The weather was excessively warm, and I was much indisposed, so that after being there a short hour, I was compelled to come home, before Mr. Hughes came in—

Mr. Chamberlain came again this morning, and brought me the two volumes of Mumfords Illiad for which I paid him five dollars and fifty cents I had received a Letter from D. G. Ingraham of Boston, asking for a copy of my correspondence, with the late William Tudor junior in May 1822, relating to the purchase, of his father’s Journals, for the Library of the Department of state.— These Journals, contain the most authentic account of the discovery of the Columbia River, by Capt. Robert Gray— I called at the Department of State this morning, and made enquiry of the Secretary Mr. Buchanan, concerning that correspondence, which was immediately found and of which he promised me a copy— I had also a conversation with him relating to the usages of the Department
with regard, to allowing access to Members of Congress, to the secret Archives, of the Department. I found the practise had continued as it was during my time, but Mr. Buchanan expressed an opinion with which I concurred that it had now become necessary to establish some restriction upon the unlimited access, of Members of Congress, to all the secret papers of the Department— The recent abuse of that privilege, by Charles. J. Ingersoll, has shown that some such restriction will be indispensable, in future— At the House, Stephens of Georgia, offered a resolution for printing four thousand copies of the map of Texas, compiled by Lieut Emory— Rhett of South Carolina objected, saying he had heard, that the map was not correct— Stephens, moved, to suspend the rules, but the House refused— The Bill from the Senate for establishing Post routes and the mail service, in Texas, was reported by Hopkins from the Post Office Committee, with an Amendment, which was adopted, and the Bill was passed, and sent back to the Senate— Committee of the whole on the State of the Union Hopkins in the Chair on the Civil and Diplomatic appropriation bill. An Amendment to diminish the pay of the Officers of Government and the members of Congress and to increase that of volunteers, to ten dollars a month—was rejected, and the Bill reported to the House, with Amendments— Several of the Amendments were adopted, among which that relating to the mileage of Members of Congress. The appropriation for the Meteorologist was struck out by yeas and nays, 92 to 77. and the Bill was passed and sent to the Senate— Committee of the whole, on the state of the Union, the resolution of thanks to General Taylor, and his troops were taken up.— James. A. Black of South
Carolina, offered an additional resolution for pensioning, the wounded Officers and Soldiers and the widows and children of the killed; which was opposed by Burt of the same state as fixing upon the Country, a gigantic Pension system— The debate slided into a contest upon merits and demerits, of the West Point Academy Ashmun, objected to one of the resolutions containing an appropriation, as un-Constitutional Brinkerhoff appealed to a precedent, in which, there was no appropriation— I referred as I have done, many times before, to the express terms, of the Constitution, to show that no appropriation, of money, can be made, by resolution— Brodhead appealed to the precedent at this Session in the resolution for the admission of Texas; which I said was only one additional violation of the Constitution The Chairman, decided that no appropriation could be made by resolution. Charles J. Ingersoll said that Chief Justice Marshall had expressly decided that a joint resolution was to all intents and purposes, a Law. Boyd the Chairman said that his decision was otherwise, Chief Justice Marshall to the contrary notwithstanding— But Ingersolls assertion was not true— Brinkerhoff appealed from the decision of the Chair Black of South Carolina had done so already— Sawyer of Ohio and Jefferson Davis of Mississippi snarled about the West-point Academy— Luther Severance, made a speech in justification of his vote against the Declaration of War, to which Barkly Martin of Tennessee replied with usual slave-monger brutality— Giddings took the floor Hudson that the Committee rise; carried 89 to 34.— In the House Bayly offered a resolution the previous Question was called but Joseph J McDowell of Ohio, said
he hoped, the gag would not be resorted to in this case. McKay offered a simple resolution of thanks, which after some slight Amendment was adopted unanimously and the House adjourned— Christopher Hughes, Robert C. Winthrop George Ashmun and William. A. Moseley dined with us— The weather oppressively warm

Mr. Kavasales was here this morning, but I could give him no cheering intelligence, and had not seen the Secretary of the Navy, since he was here last— I received from the Secretary of State, a Letter with copies of my correspondence, with William Tudor junior in May 1822. relating to the manuscripts, of Mr. Ingraham— Mr. Buchanan says, that the four volumes, of the Journals, received from Mr. Ingraham’s widow at Boston are now in the Library of the Department, and that it does not appear, that the four volumes, said to have been left in France have ever been recovered— In the House yesterday, there were, three resolutions passed, one of thanks to General Taylor, his Officers, and men, one of sympathy with the relatives and friends, and one requesting the President to communicate the others to General Taylor and through him to the Army under his command— The three were passed, by one unanimous vote, without call, for yeas, and nays— This morning Armistead Burt offered a joint resolution, for the appointment of a select Committee to consist of three Members of the House, and two of the Senate—to attend the Annual examination of Cadets of the Military Academy at West point on the first of June next, and that the
Committee be specially charged, to inquire fully and minutely into the condition of the Institution, all abuses if any, and the propriety of reducing, abolishing, or supporting and sustaining the same, and report to Congress at the present Session— After a short debate, and a motion to lay the resolution on the Table rejected 70 to 105, resolution was adopted 91. to 82, and sent to the Senate— I had not reached the House when this vote was taken— The Private callendar was taken up.— The House refused to reconsider the vote rejecting a Bill to authorize the issuing of a Patent to Charles. G. Page, and Examiner in that Office.— A motion to reconsider the vote rejecting the allowance of the fishing bounty, in the Schooner Florilla, lost at Sea, was again lost, by a tie vote 85 to 85. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Hannibal Hamlin in the Chair, on the Bill from the Senate, supplementary, to the Declaration of War against Mexico, but at the motion of George Rathbun, was laid aside to wait for the printing of the Bill— Then a Bill was taken up from the Senate making alterations in the Pay Department in the Army.— Upon which a Cong debate ensued, till the committee rose and Haralson moved a resolution to close the debate in committee in half an hour after taking it up again, but the House adjourned without taking the Question, on the motion— I was so much oppressed by the heat of the weather that I was obliged to leave the Table at dinner and Dr. Thomas was called in by my wife— I was confined at home the rest of the day— My complaints are occasioned by the premature heat of the weather and some carelessness of diet, chiefly from eating Strawberries—

I continue much indisposed under the prescriptions of Dr. Thomas, but not confined to the House— I enclosed to Mr. D. G Ingraham, the copies of my correspondence with William Tudor junior, concerning the Manuscripts, yesterday received from the Department of State— I wrote also a few lines in the Album of Miss H. M. Chapman which I delivered to her relative Mr. S. F. Chapman—who called at the House to receive them— At the House, the resolution for closing debate, on the Bill making alterations in the Pay Department of the Army, in half an hour was taken up, and modified, to allow two hours, and then was adopted— Lynn Boyd, offered a resolution for the House to meet hereafter, daily, at 10. o’clock A.M. and take a recess from two to half past three P.M. The vote was 71. to 60. not sufficient to suspend the rules, but a majority, which in a few days, will carry the resolution— Some time was allowed for the consideration of Private Bills. That for the relief of Commodore Thomas Ap Catesby Jones, was passed, without taking the yeas and nays, which were refused. After disposing of two or three other private cases, the House went again into Committee of the whole, on the state of the Union, and took up the Bill to regulate the Pay Department of the Army. A long debate ensued, and a manggling altercation between, Andrew Johnson of Tennessee, and Jefferson Davis of Mississippi upon the comparative merits of West point pupils, and blacksmiths, and tailors for Army Officers— Washington Hunt of New York, had obtained the floor, but yielded it for an explanation, to Jefferson Davis who from that time kept a running fight with Johnson
till the time for closing the debate, came and Hunt lost his chance of making a Speech— Andrew Stuart, renewed his attempt to get ten dollars a month pay for the Soldiers and volunteers, and Albert Constable of Maryland moved to strike out ten and insert twenty besides one hundred and sixty Acres of Land, which Shelton F Leake of Virginia moved should be located in Mexico After a variety of such Amendments, McKay, Chairman of the Committee of ways and means, moved to strike out the whole Bill and insert a very short one authorizing the appointment of three additional Pay Masters to serve as long as the increased number of the rank and file in the Army shall continue— This Bill was reported to the House and passed under the previous question, so expeditiously that Jacob Brinkerhoff sneerlingly inquired, if it would be in order to move that the Committee on Military Affairs should be abolished and a Legislator General appointed in its place. This was a fling at McKay Brinkerhoff being himself, a member of the Military Committee, but McKay took no notice of it— Haralson of Georgia moved to go into Committee again, upon other Bills, reported by the Military Committee but after sundry motions to adjourn and for a call of the House, the motion to adjourn was finally carried—

The weather continues oppressively warm, and my debility keeps pace with it— I attended this morning public worship in the Hall of the House of Representatives where in the place of Mr. Milburn the Chaplain of the House a stranger preached
from Hebrew 4.16. [“]Let us therefore, come boldly unto the Throne of Grace, that we may obtain mercy, and find grace to help, in time of need”— Whether from listlessness, incidental to the state of my health, or from a want of sufficient energy, in the performance of the Preacher, he left not, in my mind, an impression, distinct enough, to remember, the substance, or the drift, of his Discourse, which had at least the merit of brevity. In the Afternoon, I attended at the Second Presbyterian Church where the Revd. Matthew Hale Smith, preached his farewell sermon, the text of which was, it seemed to me, quite singular, Matthew 26–65—“Then, the high Priest rent his clothes, saying, he hath spoken blasphemy, what further need have we of witnesses, behold now ye have heard his blasphemy.” Mr. Smith related the circumstances under which, this saying of the High Priest was spoken, and whereby the Assembly of the Scribes and the Elders and all the Council, pronounced sentence of death upon Jesus Christ, and the argument of his Discourse was, upon the wickedness of rash judgments, and after handling this topic very shortly, he concluded his Discourse, by taking leave of the Society his engagement, having been to supply the Pulpit for a limited time, which had expired— He mentioned, that he himself, was of the Denomination of the Congregational Church, the Society being of what are called new school Presbyterians— Mr. Smith is a very amiable man, and I regret that his connection with this Church is not of longer duration— We had evening visits from Mr. John Healey, Mr. Archibald Campbell and Isaac Hull Adams—
